comments.comment_body: Don’t give Trump any credit for a vision of government , a plan of any kind , a policy and conceptual image of government or even a solid view of world and domestic affairs . He’s obviously a total mess . How he is POTUS is befuddling and very frightening to anyone paying attention .

Trump wants to stay out of jail.  Remaining in the White House is his only protection against spending the rest of his life in prison.  Vladimir Putin can end Trump's presidency with one phone call to the NYTimes or Washington Post, so he's forced to do Putin's bidding.  

He needs to keep his base riled up so that if he loses the election, he can claim voter fraud and threaten insurrection or even outright civil war.  He is grooming the public for a news blackout--it's been over 300 days since a press conference.  If he decides to shut down CNN and MSNBC on the grounds that they're "Enemies of the People," AG Barr will back him up and Fox News will herald his leadership.

It's really not any more complicated than that.

Ms.Hennessey and Mr. Wittes,  Thank you. A more succinct, sober and reasoned assessment of our collective predicament with The President has not been written. If ANY Democrat, but most especially President Obama, had conducted themselves in the slightest fraction of what we have daily withstood, the Republicans would have unleashed the wolves ages ago and would have brow beat, humiliated and bullied the Democrats into an impeachment. Those of you who support this atrocity know full well that this is true. You have abandoned your fellow citizens. You sow the seeds of your own demise.

"[senators] will also be judging the legitimacy of Mr. Trump’s vision [of the presidency]".

Are GOP senators really going to aquite trumps crimes as a ligitimate vision of a president?  Everything, every action, every decision is based on trump calculation of what is good for him first.  Make no mistake, a malignant narcissist has no other vision than self.

He never expected to win. It was a "What do I do now Oliver" moment. So, he does what he does best,make it a win for himself. After all he has a really, really big following that adore him and he didn't even know existed. Finally this white male's genius is acknowledge .He now owns the entire table of the 1 percenters ,and to top it off he owns the power of the commander and chief of an entire  country.

The endless list of transgressions you cited is like letting a kid loose in a candy store. 

It is imperative that his rein ends. I await the day he is a private citizen and faces the Southern District of NY. He and his brand will now be a toxic commodity. He feels alone now, just wait DJT.

Trump is a symptom of our illness; a vector but not the actual agent.  Our real and present existential threat is the GOP.  

The GOP is an united, very competent, unrelenting juggernaut against  modernity, truth, and anything that remotely opposes their regressive march toward theocratic authoritarian plutocracy (TAP).

Over the last 40 years they've insidiously and cleverly groomed  a loyal base of GOP voters.

They've  fostered apathy, confusion, and cynicism in others  to tamp down non-GOP participation.

They've gamed the system to gain unfair structural advantage.

They are really a MINORITY Party but they reign!

What Trump gives this corrupt GOP is adoring voters AND Judiciary control that assures a light brake (if any) of their march toward TAP for years to come even if they lose legislative control.

The GOP wants us to be divided; to be selfishly complacent with our insular life and view others as competitors in a zero-sum game.

They are our greatest enemy now if you truly value the ideals of liberal democracy upon which we were founded however fledgling and imperfectly.

We could survive the money oriented GOP if "all" it cared about was rational (right or wrong) free-market license.

What we will NOT survive - what we canNOT ignore as Patriotic Americans - is that this is NOT ALL the GOP wants.

I wrote many times during the electoral campaign that Trump's supporters who wanted "someone to shake things up "  reminded me of someone who drove his care off a cliff to "shake things up".  Neither the car or the person would be in a better condition, and unfortunately by electing Trump that's what we got.
Trump thinks like an absolute monarch.
The real danger of Trump is that he sees himself as The State. What matters to him is what is good for him. If this view prevails, it would be dangerous for our democracy.

Even if Donald Trump thought he really was acting to "fight corruption" in Ukraine, as the most corrupt president in our modern history he has zero credibility. The man has cheated, stolen and abused through out his entire career and adult life.There is no doubt in my mind that he is unfit to serve this great nation in any capacity. Remove him from office asap before he gets us involved in  yet another stupid, life, limb and peace threatening bruhaha. I am not a party line voter I vote for the person I think will cause the least amount of suffering here and abroad. Trump does not and will not ever measure up. I view all his sycophants in the same light. If democrats really do hate Trump it is only because they love this country and see clearly how disastrous his actions are for America and planet earth.
Plain and simple: we are at the expenses of a crook.

This is a superbly written piece. Upon reading line after line, I can't help but think that the despicable and corrupt Roy Cohn would be proud of his equally despicable and corrupt Donald J.  Just about every point made in this article applies equally to the guy who taught Trump his tricks, two peas in a rotten pod. - To the educated and astute authors, I look forward to reading your upcoming book.

The whole thing is a waste of time; the only thing keeping it afloat and sustaining any level of public interest is that it serves as an outlet for the left to ventilate their animosity to Mr. Trump; we already know they don't like him, do they need to keep telling us?  They might ask themselves why he's in the White House instead of one of their own.  Could it be that they have no compelling ideas to motivate voters to support them?

Trumps election victory was a usurpation of the political establishment. The people did not want another so called  politician in the white house. Trump has never been the one on trial in these revolutionary times, our degenerated politics are. The election in November will erase any doubts still remaining about what time it is politically in our world.

Why SHOULDN'T Trump think he can do as he wishes?   

When was the last time any President has been held accountable for any violation of the law?

The rise of the Imperial Presidency over the last 75 years has provided countless examples of Presidents who have done as they wished with no repercussions.

Apparently the listing of examples is not allowed but examples are clear to any informed reader.

Given the numerous past examples of immoral and blatantly illegal acts, why shouldn't Trump believe he can do whatever he wishes?   For all intents and purposes, the President has Sovereign Immunity.

The politicians that created the Imperial Presidency failed to anticipate the results if an 'outsider' took power.   Trump has made it blatantly obvious that our Republic is no longer functioning.

Excellent, sensible analysis.

When by law the president as chief in command can withdraw troops from Syria risking IS to rise again and can blowup a Iranian general risking a war and can order staff people not to  appear before the House because he might be impeached,  isnt  it time that Congress should seriously look into the immense and dangerous powers that are by law given to the president? The people of the US and the whole of humanity should be protected when once in 200 years a angry immature madman manages to get hold of the most powerful means in the world.

We have seen an unchecked growth of the Imperial Presidency over the last 75 years.   

Countless illegal actions by Presidents have gone unpunished, not even challenged.

Nixon was pardoned for all he did.

We had the Executive Branch arming troops  contrary to the wishes of Congress by using profits from drug running.  Pardons were issued for those caught doing so.

George W. Bush actively sought legal justification for the use of torture, got it and used that power.  The only person to be jailed because of its use was the whistle blower that revealed it.  I'll ignore the illegal war in Iraq.

The next President did not even feel that his predecessor's crimes were worth prosecuting.


Why SHOULDN'T Trump believe that the Presidency provides him with Sovereign Immunity?

When was the last time a President was actually held accountable for illegal acts?

“In the impeachment trial, senators will vote on whether to ratify the propriety of Mr. Trump’s behavior,” @Susan_Hennessey and @BenjaminWittes write, in this preview of their new book.  “But they will also be judging the legitimacy of Mr. Trump’s vision.” tweets David Priess, COO, Lawfare Institute.

Most past presidents have promised the world but have failed to deliver.  Campaign promises that have been fulfilled.  Yes that is frightening and a first.
Donald Trump is America's first king. It seems that a lot of Americans are fine with that. This year, we'll find out if we're going to stay on that path.

It doesn't look like there will be a trial, if only because Trump is popular in Kentucky and Sen. McConnell, up for re-election isn't.  If the President isn't treated with kid gloves, McConnell loses his job.  Enough Republican senators support the minimal-trial scenario to assure that the President will soon be gloating.

Trump has learned nothing his whole life. He takes the words of others - usually those who talked to him last - and runs with it, uncaring for the consequences even if it hurts him because he's incapable of thinking that far ahead. Hence the life of lies.

That a man living in the White House for three years is incapable of learning anything is astounding. The man clearly is that stupid. He defines the word.

That said, there are no words to sufficiently describe those who stand by such abject stupidity. Although, feckless, spineless, fawning sycophants come to mind for a start. The same as was said about that infamous 1930s group of henchmen.

Holding the trial allows Democrats to present evidence critical of and damaging to the President; exposing GOP Senators to down the road risks. Ms Hennessey and Mr. Wittes provides a concise description of how Trump has moved to remake the American Presidency in a manner that serves his interest above all else.  However, in this analysis that which seems to be missing is why the Congress is in such a weaken, ineffective,and corrupt state that Trump feels no compunction in using the presidency primarily for  his personal  interest.  

At a more fundamental level, the question requiring further analysis is whether value for democracy in the nation has declined to a point when a President can literally use the office for personal gain and not face any accountability from the Congress or the people. Democracy in the nation is systematically being killed at the State level by such practices as gerrymandering, voter suppression and  purges from the voter rolls.  These practices and others explain the rise of a Trump-type President and unless the American citizenry becomes aware of how and why democracy is slipping away, strange days are ahead.


wake-up,

In my life I never expected to come this close to a man who is wholly evil, and a group of people to whom "winning" is more important than not doing harm.

The violence this does to civilization, inasmuch as we live in a nation reaching for a civil society, is incalculable.

I'm inclined to ask people to return to some rather old-fashioned ideas of evil, and ask themselves if they are not worshipping a false god wholly motivated by his self-absorption, to the exclusion of the commonwealth.

Precisely. Trump does not have any higher goal than pursuit of what he sees as his self-interest. He does not care about the country or the world, he cares only about satisfying his own personal whims at any given time. As much as I disagreed with some administrations about their goals, I know that they wanted to put the nation's interests first, but I can't say that about Donald Trump.

Congress can't make us tell them what we are doing, and the courts must decide they have no jurisdiction over the Executive. A remarkably regal viewpoint, that. Separation in some degree is implied, but not stated in the Constitution, but an absolutist position today would leave Trump in a very rough spot if applied equally to all three branches. The Legislative would hold all decisions about whether to use military force. The Executive would not be able to investigate members of the other branches (ABSCAM) for criminal conduct, as Trump now refuses to allow the House to use the FBI to investigate his suspicious conduct. The Court could not declare laws duly enacted by the other two branches unconstitutional. This would be a very different republic.

The most frightening thing about Trump is the fact that what he envisions as a president has no word to describe it, but it's not the word president.

He is the last thing the founding fathers were describing when they came up with the title President of the United States of America.

Many of the powers that Trump now abuses have existed for decades. The Office of the President of the United States was created by FDR with the explicit intention of expanding executive power to act without the consent or approval of congress or the judiciary at a time when expedience and the vision he had for the country was at odds with the politics of the other branches of government.

FDR's successors have done nothing to prune back the power and privilege he gave to himself, instead they were more likely to keep adding to it. Until we arrive at the present day, where we find a supremely unworthy man suddenly given these cumulative powers, and the only thing keeping check on his nonexistent discretion is a cabal of self-interested men who believe they can exploit the chaos he creates for personal or political gain.

Trump's impeachment and removal from office would end the imminent threat he poses to our democracy, but it would not repair our democracy. To ensure another Trump does not happen the presidency's power must be truncated back to a reasonable level.

Removing trump is catching the bad actor, reducing the powers of the presidency is a step toward fixing the problem.

There are significant additional societal benefits of Medicare for All, rarely if ever discussed, that would result in major changes to the infamous US personal injury lawsuit industry.  Medicare for All would eliminate from the damages recoverable in such suits the cost of medical care for injuries received in an accident due to the negligence.  All charges for medical treatment and care are recoverable as damages in lawsuits, since under current law the injured plaintiff is legally obligated to ensure payment to medical providers for past and future expenses of care.  Such medical expenses but would not be recoverable if the costs of that care are no longer the obligation of the injured party to pay, but are rather paid by the federal government as a matter of right.

Also under current law, the past and future medical expense damages paid by defendants are shared with the attorneys for the injured, with the injured receiving only 60% of those costs for care.  With Medicare for All, the injured will be assured of full medical treatment without concern for having to share the recovery, or for running out of money for future care.

Personal injury lawsuits would still go forward for recovery of damages for pain and suffering, loss of quality of life, and similar claims.  But without need to litigate past and future medical expenses, the cost of bringing and defending such suits would be substantially reduced.  Liability insurance premiums should drop commensurately.

Underlying this entire famous and long-lasting story is the GREAT yet understated accomplishment of Marmee, essentially a single mother, who created a home life during difficult  wartime conditions , which still nurtured both body and soul of her girls. This mother encouraged fun, learning, and duty, taught her daughters the joy of giving, and gently guided them through their challenges and aspirations. (This happy,  loving, home life was the reason some of the girls did not want to "grow up" to the harshness of adulthood.)

Without the real life family experience orchestrated by her mother, the author Louisa May Alcott would not have been able to write this book. Alcott has said that her main worry was that the character of Marmee did not adequately depict the awesomeness of her own mother.

My view of this Little Women, is that it is inauthentic re: the general mores of its time. The scene where both white and black people were socializing together at a dance in Concord was preposterous, even if the Marches were abolitionists. Also the shots of well dressed blacks walking casually on the streets of NYC (or was it Boston?) is really just looking back at the 1860s with rose colored glasses. Then the characters were supposed to be teenagers but were played by actresses in their late twenties. The elaborate outfits and drapery on the wall in their attic belie their claim of poverty. This heavy handed story is what Louisa May Alcott at the time felt that she needed write to bend to the demands of her publisher, thus she was coerced into writing what she herself described as, "moral pap for the young." I can't agree more.  The moral of the story is that a woman should not be defined by or be dependent on a man. I get it, but unless we live in Yemen or South Sudan, I cannot find this a revolutionary concept nowadays. In contrast The Netflix series Anne with an E (Anne of Green Gables) written about thirty years later in Eastern Canada just north of New England. It shows a much more nuanced and realistic view of how strained and very odd were inter-racial social interactions at the time. Anne's home made clothing is plain and unadorned in contrast to that of some of her schoolmates. Anne is not described as poor at all. Anne with an E is a far more realistic story.

What I notice about Louisa May Alcott is that she was a Unitarian, as were many of her family.  She lived in Boston.  John Adams, founding father and second president of our nation, also from Boston, also a Unitarian, specifically, deliberately did not own slaves.  He did not believe in it. It's also a curious fact, documented in their diaries, that Little Women was a favorite book of the Russian Imperial family of Tsar Nicolas. Their copy of the book is in the Library of Congress. It's a historical fact that Russia did not participate in the international, transatlantic slave trade.  The government even made official protests in the day to object to its practice. Russia's most revered poet, Pushkin, was a black man by today's definition. Black people served in the Russian Imperial government and were able to advance in their profession on their merits. Another curiosity is that the women of the Imperial family trained and served as nurses during WW1, as did Louisa Alcott during the Civil war, a profession that was essentially defined and established by Florence Nightingale during the Crimean War, a war that was a humiliating defeat for the Russians, Tsar Nicolas' father.  Florence Nightingale was also a Unitarian, but she was British, an enemy of the Russians during the Crimean war.
