But we must do that while appreciating the essential humanity that we all share, So if there are no people exactly like us in a story, we can still learn from the story of others, which, in the end is part of the human story, that is also our own.

As of the last census, African Americans were somewhere around 12 % of the population of the United States.  That leaves another 88 %.  Does every cultural offering in America  need to be evaluated for proper racial content?

Beautifully written essay. There isn’t a white boy alive who hasn’t projected themselves into the story of black folks, as told through hip hop—NWA, then De La, then Tribe, Pharcyde and then Wu Tang for me. The pull of a powerful story is undeniable, it is the surest way to win hearts and minds. Imagine what the Oscars could look like if the same energy expended on Twitter were directed towards writing books or films! Perhaps the author will be the one to pull us into the story of Ellen Garrison, her empathy and eye for universal truths are evident in her writing.

"There is a fine line between a story that is about the worldview of a specific person and one that declares that this worldview is the only one that matters."

This is a very good point and I think something that a lot of the social media armchair critics miss. Most pieces of fiction will by necessity be about a specific world view; in fact it is pretty much impossible for an individual piece of fiction to perform an in-depth survey of a wide range of world views simply because fiction usually needs to focus on a particular set of characters/place/theme/etc, which inherently constrains the range of experience that is explored.

At the end of those who complain about a piece of media focusing on white characters (or those from another privileged demographic) aren't really addressing the real problem. The real problem isn't that media focusing on white characters gets made, it's that media focused on characters who aren't white gets produced/published/hyped at a lower rate because of bias against these stories. Pointing out that one individual piece of media focuses on white characters is usually completely orthogonal to the real problem. I guess people find it easier to deal with a single anecdote rather than to try to look at the data, which is where the story really is.

Perhaps this editorial should be followed up by another which takes up the issue that not a single female director was nominated for an Academy Award.  This should make all of us, men and women, black or white, angry. Ms Gerwig did an artful job of directing a beautiful movie and did not receive her just reward.

"Let’s stop imagining ourselves in white stories and instead create our own."

And there you have it in a nutshell. This novel was written based on a specific worldview when it was written.  Let's just be realistic that this perspective wasn't meant to encompass people with other cultures or historical narratives. That's not necessarily good or bad, it just is. 

The reality is we live in a country were people are separated by social class, income. race, religion and political viewpoints among other things. There are both white and black people in this country that have little if any contact with each other either at all or only within the confines of work. 

For some white people, black people simply do not exist, and that is reflected in the literature, movies, and television shows that they write. Most black people do not have this option. There about about 5 times as many white people in America are there are black people. We are literally bombarded with their culture in the media. 

However, we have our own stories to tell. They are beautiful provocative and rich. We have proven time and again we have the creative minds to tell these stories. Let's just go about the business of telling them.

As I child, reading gave me the ability to travel to other worlds, and other lives. Like thousands of young girls, I was smitten with the March sisters precisely because I l wanted an attic full of costumes, and a place to write. And three sisters. Their lives were quite unlike my own. They even had a cook! But I also remember discovering the exotic world of caliphs, at eight, and learning about the wicked Russian Baba Yaga as I read fairy tales from around the world. And who can forget the wonderful All-of-a-Kind Family: a large Jewish family at the turn of the century? I wanted to time travel right into their humble parlor. And while there were no books with children of color, except Just So Stories, my ten year old's book case had an autobiography of Wilma Rudolph. I read her amazing story over and over. I wanted to be Wilma Rudolph, too! For a kid, I had a pretty expansive world view, because of books. And from there, it was a hop and a skip to Zora Neale Thurston, Toni Morrison, Alex Haley and James Baldwin, etc.

 I'm glad this lovely writer can appreciate the March girls and their journey for what it is.

Thank you for this.  Little Women was of a time, and place, and certain people, but still has  universal value.  And thank you for your appreciation of A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, also of a time, and place, and certain people, but also universal.   Both books were of immense value to me as young reader.

When I was a white child growing up in Mississippi in the fifties and sixties, I longed to have a black friend. But that entire world was taboo, just as it was taboo for a black girl to have a white friend. I'm sure there were exceptions to this in rural areas, but this was the reality for most of us, and the "other race" because mysterious curiosities for both black and white children. Since I couldn't befriend a black child, I tried to find books about black children at the library, but there were none to be checked out. So, during the summers, I wrote my own "novels" in pencil on lined paper about the adventures of black children. They had the same 'clubs,' loving parents, and skinned knees that I had. I still have those little novels, though the words are fading and the paper is yellowed, and when I re-read them recently, I realized I'd created an unreal world: the characters I'd created had libraries, good schools, restaurants. It was a world that mirrored my own. Jim Crow created such a horrible separation of races that it kept white children shamefully ignorant of the violent realities of racism. Not until a few years later did we realize that our black counterparts did not even have libraries. . .

I remember having the privilege to hear Maya Angelou speak at the University of Virginia in the early 90s - she said that as a young 13 year old, having survived very difficult circumstances, she read Shakespeare's "When in disgrace with Fortune and men's eyes, I all alone be weep my outcast state..." and knew with certainty that Shakespeare was talking directly to her, a little black girl. I think that's the power of timeless literature - it does not matter for whom or by whom it was written, though the story is by necessity of the age in which it was written - you can find a personal connection to it. And I, growing up the youngest of four sisters in India, loved "Little Women", as did my sisters, and found various mappings between us and the March sisters (though I must admit I hated being the "Amy" of the family - something Greta Gerwig's wonderful adaptation has made me feel better about).

Beautiful piece--thoughtful, nuanced, wise, progressive, empathetic.  As one who is trying to figure how to still love the so-called "American literary canon" and recognize and be committed to reading about peoples left out of that canon, I really appreciate your thoughts. Will think about them this afternoon as I take my Mom to the movie.

Oh, good Lord.
People stop putting so much weight on a book written in1868,  Its a good story that speaks to many people.  It is not a manifesto nor a guide to the universe nor a guide for living.  Enjoy the window into another place and another time.   And then go read another book.

This is a white womans memoir of her life, as she saw it then. I see the point of not seeing yourself in the characters and most popularized masterpieces of writing. But Lousia May Alcott, was writing about the experience in her body and her relationship to her sisters and the world that immediately affected her life. We cant look back and want a piece of art to be and include what we want it to with a 21st century pov. We should enjoy it for what it is, and I think as a female it can reach us all on many levels. (and men too)  Perhaps we should highlight more books about and make more films from the young black female perspective in the future as well. But this isnt the place and it isnt there soo...

Thank you so much for this brilliant piece. As a fellow insatiably curious reader and thinker, you are absolutely correct that the kind of conversations you have with your sisters are rare, heartbreakingly slow. I have done all I can to maintain this worldview throughout my whole life and as I enter middle age, it seems to be becoming more rare. 

As much as I adored the book and the movie, as a white woman, who was born and raised on a farm, with an intellectual, progressive family with three daughters, the book spoke to the deepest parts of my soul. As a grown white woman, watching the movie, at least 10 times during the movie, I was wondering how a black woman would experience it. Thank you for giving us such passionate, loving, and thoughtful look into your soul.

It’s a testament to the scarcity of films by and about women that Little Women is being spotlighted and lambasted for its whiteness. Are there any major black characters in The Irishmen? Ford vs. Ferrari? Etc., etc., etc?

Ms. Greenridge:  Thank you for this very wise piece of writing.  I am going to seek out more by you.   Your point should be taken: Empathize with others including fictional characters not entirely like yourself.   Art is not about looking in a mirror but seeing a refraction of your own experience.  I am glad you enjoyed the film Little Women - I did too.  I think the other point in your article worth noting is the invitation to creation.  We need more new stories as well as retellings of many old stories where we will find diversity of experience and outlooks too.  Thank you again for such a thoughtful piece.
This essay is written with a beautiful and generous spirit. And it’s worth listening to.

All of this should be taken into consideration with the REAL life of the REAL Louisa May Alcott.

Alcott loathed and despised "Little Women" -- she wrote it for money and nothing else. She held her fans in contempt. (Look it up!)

I recently saw a wonderful documentary about Alcott, made for PBS ("Louisa May Alcott: The Woman Behind Little Women") and it was fascinating and very richly detailed. If only Greta Gerwig had had the originality and insight to make a truthful biopic about LOUISA and not (yet another!) vapid edition of "Little Women".

Truth is nearly always more fascinating than fiction.

“I sit with Shakespeare, and he winces not. Across the color line I move arm and arm with Balzac and Dumas, where smiling men and welcoming women glide in gilded halls. From out of the caves of evening that swing between the strong-limbed Earth and the tracery of stars, I summon Aristotle and Aurelius and what soul I will, and they come all graciously with no scorn nor condescension. So, wed with Truth, I dwell above the veil. Is this the life you grudge us, O knightly America? Is this the life you long to change into the dull red hideousness of Georgia? Are you so afraid lest peering from this high Pisgah, between Philistine and Amalekite, we sight the Promised Land?” I have often thought of this quote from W.E.B. Du Bois when I have read articles questioning the universality of certain works of literature. This was an interesting column, and the writer makes some good points.

Why does every movie have to have a "Black" connotation?  There were such things as white women struggles back in the time frame portrayed.  African Americans forget that other people have struggles as well.  They don't own struggle.  

It is ok to have a different perspectives.  That doesn't make one set of struggles any less valid.

The “Brothers Karamasov” isn’t aimed at black experience either: it’s aimed at human experience more generally. No complaint about that. 

The author notes that black American authors have become more mainstream — encouraging this trend is the way forward, not complaining about the parochialism of white authors.

When you are a hammer, everything looks like a nail....

Perhaps forgotten in this "woke" environment, but African Americans represent ~ 14% of the U.S. population, and AA women ~50% of that figure.  That may be why AA literature is not as representative as the author would like.

Uh, yeah, the characters in 19th century Alcott's story were white.  Should we change the skin color of the characters in Walter Mosley's fiction? Is his worldview the only one that matters?  Does it have merit on its own basis?

The term “Black Irish” did not originally apply to skin color, hair color or eye color, but to “dark” or “evil” intent. The Black Irish are descendants of immigrants (Vikings and Normans) who were not Celtic and came to Ireland as invaders but assimilated and acculturated. They formed their own clans and sub-sets . The explanation that the Black Irish are descendants of Spanish sailors who washed ashore when storms wrecked the Spanish Armada is not taken seriously. https://www.irishcentral.com/roots/history/who-were-the-black-irish

Unlike most reviewers, I found the movie cloying and unbelievable. The March family is supposed to be poor — though not destitute — but there is a sumptuous costume change in every frame. The girls are all so talented, but their talent seems to have been thrust upon them, deux ex machina, not earned through hard work. The male figures are much kindlier than those I have encountered in the work place. But what got my goat the most was the final, idyllic scene, in which boys and girls, brown, black, and white, frolic together in their new school. If only that had been the case! I found it facile and demeaning to pretend that it was so.
Well, there's the Brewster Place series

It's funny. As a boy, I was never interested in reading "Little Woman"; as a man, I have no particular interest in seeing the movie, no matter the race of the characters. So, yes, I can understand Ms. Greenidge's viewpoint as a black woman in regards to the white cannon. Ironic, no?
In the name of minority subjective definitions of inequality the war on whiteness goes on.

This piece and the detractors it highlights commit the frequent and egregious error, which for some reason is often unaddressed, of grouping all White people together as some weird monolith.

I am Italian and Irish American and I am pretty sure my ancestors are not portrayed in Little Women. I also do not recall any Jewish characters or characters from Hungary, Spain, Poland, or countless other European countries with largely Catholic populations. The characters in Little Women are WASPs, which is a very specific form of White. 

Still, despite this, I can enjoy the work for being a literary masterpiece. Just like I enjoyed The Color Purple. I am not sure this article is particularly helpful by focusing on the tweets of a handful of bitter and uninformed critics. 

Let the detractors toil in their own biased fueled ignorance.

As an early reader, and now a “senior” who still reads voraciously, am I the only white girl reader who read but very much disliked Little Women? Even before I learned what the concept of literary archetypes was.
This book, and all great art, is about what humans have in common, what unites them, not what divides them.
One of the great pleasures of reading newspapers is encountering a piece like this which helps me, an old white guy, see another's perspective and understand a little more about the world.

Thank you, Ms. Greenidge, for a thoughtful and useful piece!
I really don't know what one can say about what comes down to ethical taste?: I am a middle-aged white woman and got so much -- on artistic, psychological, intellectual, and emotional levels (to varying degrees) -- out of, just for example, the Hollywood-ish films "Moonlight," "Hidden Figures," "Black Panther"...
Every story isn't going to be perfectly representative of the exact make up of our modern society down to the percentage.  Nor does it need to be.

I find the infusion of racial identity in literature very unsettling. As a child and young adult, I read classics and fiction as recreation of a story that was independent of me or my racial identity. I visualized the characters in my mind based on their context, not mine. 

They did however address larger themes that were common across the board- love, hatred, friendship, family, war, peace, etc.  That is what mattered to me and if I felt that the author had brought it out skillfully, I was moved by it. 

Why does everything have to be about oneself all the time?

Hopefully it also seems some folks of all races and ethnic backgrounds today are intently interested (as measured by best-seller lists) in another book about childhood experience and heartache and growth a hurt and self-definition and grit -- this time about a sister and brother growing up in America during a tumultuous and divisive wartime with limited financial resources. Perhaps more than a few white  girls (including my daughters)  will read have read Michelle Obama's story with the same identification and empathy you experienced with "A Tree grows in Brooklyn."

I loved your article.  There is something special and timeless about a well crafted story.  We humans are much more alike than the visible differences created by “race” or “ethnicity” that it is not difficult to connect with the characters.  Please write more stories!

I grew up first generation in an Italian household, loving reading and not being able to get enough of it. 

Natasha in "War and Peace" is Russian. I was enthralled by her. Wild Bill Hickok -- I devoured the book about him after I saw my older brother reading it. (That certainly got me weird comments from other girls at school.) Cathy and Heathcliff in "Wuthering Heights" knocked my socks off. I became completely immersed in the adventures of the heroes in "Treasure Island" and "The Count of Monte Cristo." On and on.

It never occurred to me that none of the characters in the books I was reading were Italian or Italian-American. Or even that they were male or female. I didn't care.

The stories spoke to me. That's the point. But I guess I shouldn't be surprised by all this hand-wringing over so-called identity. 

How about this for identity? I'm human. 

Or as the Roman poet Horace put it ages ago: "Homo sum, humani nihil a me alienum puto" -- "I am human, I consider nothing human alien to me."

Sun Tzu is often quoted for writing “know your enemy” in The Art of War.  For minorities like me, reading dead white people literature is all about knowing your enemy.  We have to read it anyway for grades.  How many of us read Catcher in the Rye, Lord of the Flies, Moby Dick, Old Man and the Sea...and the list goes on.  And it continued with Shakespeare (I love it when old white dudes call him “the Bard”...), Joyce and an endless parade of dead white folks.

As a child, I never saw myself in any of this work.  But early on, I realized it was a window into how white people think, how they see the world.  And that’s how I approached dead white people literature:  like Napoleon Chagnon studying the Yanomamo.  It helped me understand what they were saying to me, and what they needed me to say to them at:  interviews, arguing in court for the judge, corporate retreats and on the squash court at... insert name of ivy club here.

Now in my old age, I’m happy that my daughter saw the new Little Women.  She said she couldn’t relate to it, but it gave a view on the lives of white women in that period.  That’s exactly what I want her to see.  We’re not the target market, but she sees what they’re saying to that target market.

On the topic of Irishness mentioned briefly in this excellent piece: Louisa May Alcott endorsed "No Irish Need Apply" and wrote a newspaper column lamenting the laziness and stupidity of Irish maids. I am an Irish immigrant and while this piece of history is supremely disappointing to me, I still love Little Women. I only mention this, not to co-opt the issue of racial diversity which is much different than cultural prejudices that exist among different groups of white people, but to add another perspective of a reader who has to overlook imperfect history.

At the end, Kaitlyn Greenidge declares that "the questions should be an invitation to creation, not an end to conversation."

I wish somebody--maybe a black woman novelist or screenwriter?--would create something along the lines of the little-known children's novel "Lottie's Courage," about a young black girl in the Civil War.  

Lottie comes from the imagination of Phyllis Hall Haislip, a white woman. Haislip tells of Lottie's escape from enslavement as part of the self-emancipation movement that historians increasingly recognize--but that the public mostly doesn't yet recognize--as having forced transformation of the Civil War into a struggle for freedom. 

No one should fault the 1619 Project for demanding truth-telling about a quarter-millennium and more of crimes against humanity, though some critics have been doing something along those lines. But at the same time, more people should respect the brave initiative and black agency through which people like Lottie forced the transformation.

Lottie's courage sustains her in a long, perilous escape to freedom at Fort Monroe, which in real life was the Union's mighty, and mighty symbolic, bastion in Confederate Virginia. 

The 1619 Project knows Fort Monroe as Point Comfort, but the project unfortunately sees it mostly as the place where slavery began--even though it's also the place where self-emancipators forced slavery to begin to crumble. 

Yes indeed, let's see "an invitation to creation, not an end to conversation."

I loved this option piece. The writer is wise and wonderful.  And, I loved the movie. 
White readers, like me, must also enter black character’s minds when reading black authors. I believe Toni Morrison’s “Beloved” to be one of the most important, if not the most important, book of the 20th Century. “Little Women” is a wonderful book, but not in same rank as “Beloved.” Nevertheless, I loved the both book and movie.

I (white lady, ivory tower, flyover zone) have given a fair amount of thought to the tension between on the one hand, reading's ability to reveal new worlds and develop empathy for others who are very different, and on the other hand, the need for young readers to see that stories about people like themselves are worth telling. I really appreciated the nuanced take in this piece.  Some commentators here suggest that because they themselves can make the leap to any sort of protagonist in a novel, it must be that anyone can do so. Not so; it's a skill that comes with extensive reading, and the data show that our young people (of any race) very often fall short of proficiency and don't read much. Having protagonists transparently similar to the reader and having empathy flow both ways (to quote Ms. Greenidge) are necessary to developing readers who can reap the benefits of a broad range of fiction.

I first read Little Women as an 8 year old girl in India (and then many times again over the next few years). I knew only a little bit about the American Civil War when I first read it, so I didn't fully appreciate the context, but regardless for me the central draw was Jo, and it never even occurred to me to think that she was white - she was a tomboy, and a bookworm, and loved words, and felt keenly the injustices of being a woman in a man's world - and I saw myself in her, and LOVED the book (and wanted to smack Amy and thought Laurie was a silly clueless boy and found Beth too annoyingly good to be true, etc.). In other words, the book was a central part of my early years as a reader, as were the Little House books (and Black Beauty, and the Black Stallion books, and Enid Blyton) - with main protagonists all whiter than white for the most part - but so were the great Indian stories, Norse mythology, Russian fairy tales, the Grimms, Isaac Asimov and Arthur C. Clarke. My point is that great literature, whether children's or otherwise, transcends race and country and speaks directly to our imaginations - and if we couldn't see ourselves in those characters, then it would be a sad thing indeed. 

Having said that, we do need more black voices on the page and on the screen (I've lived here more than half my life now, and I see that most white Americans are blind to the true history and continuing reality of racial injustice in America) so this is a good conversation to have.
Thank you for your thoughtful piece.  Life is complicated.

"Let’s stop imagining ourselves in white stories and instead create our own."
Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes!  (Yes, I could go on repeating.)  I read "Kindred" by Octavia Butler, and it serves as a wonderful example.  Ms. Greenidge writes a superb "conversation" here.  Other people who merely complain about a lack of showing diversity in art don't do the immense need for it any justice.  It even risks mockery, like Ricky Gervais spoke about not including the memorial at the Golden Globes because the dead artists were mostly white.

As we continue down the road of identity politics and preoccupation with identity, our democracy will suffer by splintering any counterpoint to the right.

By obsessing about which group is oppressed more, people like Ms. Greenidge will unknowingly ensure that the answer will be all of us.

If people of any race or ethnicity want to read more stories about their own race they should write more of it. Those who complain about such things also raise objections when others with great imagination author stories of strangers. There are barriers to making non-white movies in Hollywood, but fewer obstacles in fiction writing. There is always free on demand publishing on Amazon.

I loved the movie, and I also loved For Black Girls Who have Considered Suicide /when the rainbow is enuf. I wanted to be black after reading that. I think the job of good writing is to transport you, envelop you, whatever you. It’s true that my cultural baggage does not include the kind of score keeping that is mentioned in this article, but I think I get it: Even though this was a period piece, the town had black families and could have represented that perspective better than by just showing one woman of color. 

In The Irishman, it bothered me that the daughter never spoke about her feelings for her father’s job. You always knew what she felt, but even as an adult she never said anything. We never know what any of the women in that movie actually thought. It was intimated, but never expressed. Is this the same kind of resentment?

Stories are engaging when they are about people who are fully privileged to participate in their society and make a full range of choices.  We want to identify with people who have both opportunities and challenges  and see what they do with it.  People of color so often have such restricted opportunities that their lives just don't have the makings of good stories that help most of us learn, unless the settings are relatively modern or fantastical.  The appeal of stories about coping with oppression will always be niche but needed, like cures for rare diseases.

“A Tree Grows in Brooklyn” was and still is one of my favorite novels.  I like that the characters seem like real people (unlike Little Women) plus I had a complicated relationship with my mother so I felt a connection with Francie on this issue though I am neither white nor Irish.  Here’s hoping the film will not be remade (again), the 1940s version is fine as is.

NYT should publish more opinion pieces like this.

Ms. Greenidge sublimely blends her knowledge of history, literature, film and cultural studies with her awareness of current social norms and an intimate understanding of her own family dynamics and limitations to provide insight and stimulate  intellectual debate.  As a nation, we need to share and shake our perceptions, engage in pointed but respectful conversations committed to truth and honesty and humbly but confidently challenge ourselves and others to improve our state of discourse and the conditions in which we live.  I staunchly defend this course as non-elitist, but true to the best intentions of democratic activity.  

Thanks to Kaitlyn Greenidge for using her skills, knowledge and good intentions to further collective understanding and to challenge readers to engage with art, history and our current state in ways that might prompt the dynamism - even the heated tumult - required to right our wobbling democracy.  

It does us well, in this regard, to study and consider the conditions - for people of color, women, and immigrants - and events that led to the United States Civil War, the broader social context for Little Women.  History is not predetermined.  The United States, as we envision it in our gauzy and subjective ideals, is always a work in progress.  That work is ours.  Conversations stimulated by Ms Greenidge and others assist us in our labors.

Great essay. I will say this: I am a European born male who emigrated and grew up in the "inner city." We read the cannon. Especially Shakespeare, but also the Bronte sisters, Dickens, Joyce, Hemingway, Wolfe, et al. Interestingly, maybe because the school system where I attended High School was hugely, predominately, black and latino (as in: you could count the white kids, of which I was one, in one hand)  we also read Richard Wright, Frederick Douglass, Sandra Cisneros, Alice Walker, Toni Morrison, Sherman Alexi, Lorraine Hansberry, August Wilson, James Baldwin, Ralph Ellison. I believe my conception of literature and life has been enriched by these readings. I am shocked that American children do not read these books, and authors, as I consider them to be part of the western cannon. When we read these books, we were meant to not just improve our reading comprehension, but to also learn about cultures and experiences outside our own. That, however, does not mean that a book (and, I suppose, though wholly unnecessary, a film) like Little Women is not valid and should not be written/produced/seen/considered. It should. What is unquestioned, I believe, is that the variety of what is read in school, should be expanded across the board, to include multiple perspectives and voices.

A lovely column.  As a elderly white male, I may not have expected to immediately identify with the points made by the columnist. Yet, I did.

I first found Little Women at age 12. I promptly fell in love with the story and characters.  Growing up, I also read and enjoyed books written by Octavia Butler and Toni Morrison. 

I do agree that I don't have the experience of being an ethnic minority female reader, wondering how they would fit into the world of Little Women. What matters most to me is that I can relate to  certain characteristics.

I wonder if framing this as "we need more stories about black girls for black girls" is less necessary/productive than saying "we need more stories about black girls for everyone else". People of color know who they are, its the rest of the world that needs an education and needs to change. Personally I'm more excited about the men and boys who are going to see this film than the women and girls who are.

What extraordinary, beautiful writing.

I am about to read your novel, We Love You Charlie Freeman, and we all await your next book, Ms Greenidge.

Does everything have to be filtered through a lens of blackness?  This wonderful story was written about a white family.  Does everything in hindsight have to be altered to accommodate racial diversity. It is stiff and awkward.   I don't expect revisionist history either in the attempt at racial inclusion.  
Imagine if, in a film about black people, people complained about no whites.  Imagine if white people said they could not relate to the black characters because they were black. I don't think that would go over too well, just like this commentary did not go too well with me.  

 I try and relate to characters in literature and film regardless of race or culture, perhaps the author should too.

Thank you for this essay. We spend too much energy identifying how we are different rather than what we share. I read this book as a Mexican-American girl growing up in a farmworking community because there wasn’t much more available. Since then, the  breadth of what I’ve read has dramatically increased, but this is still an important book from my childhood.

Thank you for a good article, though I'm sorry that in these times one must feel compelled to explain that literary characters often embody universal concerns that are not tied to race (e.g., essential questions such as 'who am I?' and "what am I to make of my life in this society?") And it's telling that this  division and potential boycotting is aimed at a story that focuses on women and girls. Not sure I've heard people wringing their hands over movies featuring white men like this.

Movies, books, and plays about white people's lives are not too numerous in absolute terms, they are just too  numerous proportionately.  There is not a need to reduce the number of stories about white families, couples, individuals, friends, but rather a need to increase the number of stories about Black, Latino, Asian, and Native lives.  As such, it remains necessary to point out to writers like Ms Greenidge that white people will continue to respond to their stories, just as People of Color will continue to respond to theirs, and hopefully all people of all ethnicities, religions, and ages will find common stories that strike a chord will all.  I personally continue to want stories like The Adventures of Augie March.  That book speaks to me in ways that Between the World and Me never will.  That doesn't mean I think Coates has an obligation to speak to me too.  He has his beautiful book that speaks to some,  Bellow has his book that speaks to some, Atwood has her books that speak to some, etc.  This idea, though, that certain stories are making a transgression because they don't speak to every group's experience is an impossible standard that no writer, not Coates, not Bellow, not Atwood, should always be expected to achieve.

I empathize with Ms. Greenridge’s experience of lacking fiction that spoke to her as a young African-American girl. I am a white woman who grew up in a generation when the bulk of classic literature we were given to read as kids was about men and boys, and even though I enjoyed a lot of it, the feeling seldom left me, as I read, that those stories were not about me.  Girls of my generation loved Nancy Drew because she realized the potential we felt deep down we had, if we could only be given the space to use it.  And we loved Little Women because for a lot of us, including me, it was Jo’s story we identified with, a coming-of-age story about a girl in whose tomboy personality and wish to break from traditional women’s roles we saw ourselves.  Her success was our success, a permission to rebel and become something more in the world. We all need stories like that as children; they help form us by giving us a sense of a future we can make.

I found Ms Greenridge's article to be an important expression of  appreciation for the universality of people's experiences as expressed and experienced in the reading of historically based fiction. Race, religion, class and gender are factors that influence both an individual's sense of self and worldview. But as readers we are able to move beyond the limitations of our own identities when reading narrative fiction about the experiences of those from whom we differ.  As a history teacher who used recent historical fiction & memoirs in teaching about Asia, I saw literature serve my readers by both relating dramatic differences and emphazing a common humanity they could feel and relate to, no matter their own personal identities.

Clueless White Guy, here:

Maybe I'm wrong, but it seems to me that much of the potential discomfort Ms. Greenidge's describes about the "Little Women" phenomenon isn't really about the book or the movie, itself.  It has more to do with the whole mythology which has grown up around this story since it was first published in 1868-69 and subsequently embraced by so many generations of (mostly white) girls.  Especially the whole thing about "which March sister are you?" because "Every girl, it is decided, must be in some part a Jo, a Meg, a Beth or an Amy."  It seems to me that Ms. Greenidge is gently reminding us that there are a whole lot of other possibilities beyond those four, supposedly universal, types of girls.

Beyond that, I wholeheartedly agree with all the comments here saying that literature is an engine for empathy.  Thank God for the Toni Morrisons and James Baldwins and Zora Neale Hurstons and Richard Wrights who have done so much to expand the American literary canon.  It's not fair to expect every book to reflect every person's viewpoint.  But it's important to include a wider range of viewpoints by welcoming bold and talented new voices to the canon.

This is for the most part a good and enjoyable piece but the gyrations the author feels necessary to go through to see she likes the movie are depressing.  Here's just one:

"There's a fine line between ... and a piece of art that declares that this worldview is the only one that matters and is fatally incurious about all others."  

Seriously?  How many good pieces of art (the ones worth talking about) declare their worldview is the only one?  This doesn't really happen.  Or, certainly it is the rare exception. Yet the author feels compelled to raise this specter just so she can say Little Women is not part of it and therefore it's ok for her to like the movie.

Louisa May Alcott and her fellow transcendentalists were monumental in the fight against slavery and racism. In addition to this, Alcott's writings were strikingly feminist for the time and inspired countless women to turn away from mindless vanity and celebrate individualism. Why in the world should we forget this moving story simply because there aren't any black characters? Sigh

I loved this piece.  Thank you.  

My 10th grade public school English teacher in the 1970s assigned great novels from different perspectives: Grapes of Wrath, A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, The Bluest Eye.  

Of all of these, Toni Morrison is the author I loved and have continued to read.  Her books are my Tree Grows in Brooklyn.

I read Little Women as well and thought it was sentimental bosh.

The best authors, directors, art speak to us because they or their work speak to all of us.  Or those willing to give their work a chance.

I learned that in 1978 in Memphis, TN from a wonderful public school teacher who happened to be African American and opened the eyes of a young girl from an entirely different background to work that was more meaningful for me than Little Women.

I may or may not see Little Women.  But I won't make the decision based on the gender or race of the author, filmmaker or cast.  If I'd done that in an English class in 1978, but life would be less rich.

This is a stunningly brilliant and superbly written article.  Thank you so much for writing this.

While I agree with your views on this subject, I must point out what's also missing from this dialogue is the fact many youngsters aren't reading much any longer.  This is a very disturbing fact.

As a child, I read voraciously and my imagination was sparked by the books I read.  I identified with many of the characters I encountered along the way and not all of them were of my race.

Part of learning your way through life is to see others, often those with whom you have nothing in common and gaining both insight and knowledge from their travails.

Without this background to anchor us in changing world of ideas, laws and expression, we turn to others and the media for clarity, and often, this is a negative and restrictive world view.

We're missing out on a vast spectrum of creativity and ideas.

For me, the major issue with all the adaptations of Little Women is in the lack of diversity in looks - the cast is invariably made up of extremely attractive women. 
In the US, there seems to be no place for "ordinary" looking women in major films - even in films where being ordinary looking is part of the character.

Ms. Greenidge seems to have been ill-served by the worldview that racial differences are paramount and that relevance of a work of art, novel, film, news story, political candidate, etc. hinges on their identity group. As a result, she feels that her appreciation for a book represents some sort of betrayal of her race or ideology. She should not have to explain herself for enjoying and learning from Little Women. Sadly, modern Liberal thinking wants her to reject this book and the movie. Sadly, modern Liberal thinking can't see past identity. Sadly, modern Liberal thinking ignores all the other components that make works like these important. It's not the particulars (although they may be interesting) but the universality. Liberals should be highlighting the universal attributes of great art that bring people together. Greenidge seems to understand this. It's a shame she needs to defend this understanding.

If you only see the world of books through your own gender or skin color you will sadly miss a lot of great stories and adventures. However, if you can break away from an identity politics driven label and open your mind you can enjoy numerous great stories written by so many people. 

Not every story is for everyone. There are plenty out there though to enjoy if you think of yourself more than your skin color.

Saw it this weekend. It is an excellent movie. I long ago quit trying to get some subliminal message from film. It is just an enjoyable movie, with a great script and cast.  Everything in this country is not about race.

I think it’s a baby and bath water issue. I certainly think there should be more representation of any and all in the arts, but that should not diminish existing art. I am a white middle aged male and perhaps my favorite author is James Baldwin. I don’t identify exactly with the experiences he describes, but I personally identified strongly with the sense of alienation and struggle in my own way and learned something deep and meaningful about the African American experience to boot. And as a lover of literature, how could I not love the pure beauty of his writhing? I’m well aware that I have it easy as a reader and can take for granted my own representation, an experience that can not be discounted. But that should not rule out a young black girl loving Catcher In The Rye as I did as a teenager and more than I loved Beloved. In great writing there is a universality in the particular. In these times people like myself are being asked more forcefully than ever to look more closely at our privilege and representation, and rightfully so. But to some extent the flip side of that coin is to love and accept good art on it’s own terms even if one doesn’t see themselves exactly in it and not to trash the shortcomings of the past or the good faith efforts of the present. Hopefully we can add to the canon. We need to.

Thank you very much for writing this.  I saw this movie with my two daughters and was just happy to have a film I could see with my daughters that we could have a conversation about.  There are already way too few movies with a range of females in them.  Yes, we don't have to keep remaking the same one and yes, there are so many other women's stories that need to be told but that doesn't mean we never have to revisit this one.  I almost didn't take my daughters to see this, despite my younger one wanting to, because of the backlash.  However, what prompted me to do it was remembering how big a part the book plays in the book "My Brilliant Friend."  In that book, two small girls in a pretty bleak city in Italy where most girls aren't schooled beyond age 10 because it's viewed as a waste, are so thrilled to find a book written by a woman about women that it drives them forward to seek out an education.  While "My Brilliant Friend" was a work of fiction, I do imagine "Little Women" encouraged many girls to keep reading, to keep learning, to keep striving.

"It is worthwhile to point to the absences, the silences, the erasures in stories. But the questions should be an invitation to creation, not an end to conversation."

So absolutely brilliant. Creating empathy for the unknown is a central function of stories; but they are necessarily stories about one thing and not another. That does not make them exclusionary. I love the way that Greenidge describes her personal adaptation "A Tree..."  I did that myself as a country girl who dreamed of the city. I did that as a non-Jew reading Anne Frank's diary. And reading Tolstoy's Anna Karenina as a non-Russian. "Things fall apart" (Achebe), "The New Miss India" ... everything by Isabel Allende... and so many more. Neil Gaiman had it right when he said that stories are living, organic things that we need to live.

I recently read The Bluest Eye for the first time, and though I'm a 57-year-old white woman, I found myself identifying with Pecola.  Pecola's certainty of her own ugliness is something I suspect all girls suffer, if not because of their race, then because of something else--a physical disability, a slight imperfection, a constant barrage of disparagement.  For me, the reading experience has always been about putting myself into the skin of a character, becoming that character, living that character's life.  Just as I became Pecola for awhile, I've also become Jo March during the times I've read Little Women.  But I've also been Flush, Virginia Woolf's dog, and Pi, the narrator of Life of Pi.  Good literature transports and transforms you--you become a character, and then you carry a bit of that character with you forever.

Little Women was a foundation of my reading as a little girl growing up in the 1940s, a period of time that means I grew up before women began to push for more rights.   Rereading it now, I see that it is from this book I learned that life is an exercise in self improvement.   It is from this book that I learned that people set goals for themselves and the development of their character.    And it seems to me now that I didn't question how Jo, a mere girl, was able to get her writing published.  I just accepted it as the way things should be.   And I always wanted to be a tomboy, like Jo.  I just assumed that of course, Jo was everyone's favorite.    Thinking back now, I don't think I ever had much interest in any of the sisters but Jo.      In light of the women's movement, I find these realizations very interesting.   I will mull on these thoughts and this column for days.

I am always so happy to meet another fan of "A Tree Grows In Brooklyn"!

I would like to suggest Betty Smith's other works - "Tomorrow Will Be Better", "Joy In The Morning" - and most especially "Maggie-Now"

I have no real interest in seeing this film and the book never appealed to me, even though I appreciate the fact that in both cases, it represents the view of women - for women - at a time when the feminine voice was extremely marginalized.
Fine. 
But that marginalization still comes nowhere near what non-white women in America have had to experience, and so that in itself is a rather limited perception.
And I say this a bi-racial person who has had the advantage of being raised in two different cultures -- both in the U.S. and Europe, where the book "Little Women" is regarded as a epic piece of classic literature, but not in the same way that it is here.
That said, it's all very well that the most recent film version of it was made, and doubtless it will be well received and regarded as a work of art by a certain segment of the public.
But critically speaking, that doesn't necessarily mean that it is something for everyone.

In a diverse society it's always possible that you're going to come across stories that don't involve your particular group.   Every time I read a religion-based story in the Times, it's inevitably about either Catholics or evangelicals .  Both groups treat their own denomination as "The Church" and act as if other churches don't exist.  Neither group allows women to join the clergy, so the writer treats this as a universal rule and complains that "religion is patriarchial"  The difference is that in fiction a writer can choose what characters to portray, while a newspaper is supposed to give an accurate picture of society.

So happy to read this article.   Little Women has been and remains one of the most popular and greatest novels not because of its Whiteness, but because of its greatness.   I am so happy that it reaches you as it does - and isn't wonderful that this book still can do that in spite of its age and pertinence to another time entirely?

What Greenidge's thoughtful article discusses in terms of race, I found, as a young person, in terms of gender. All the most exciting characters in the novels I read were male. Even in graduate school when a male professor asked me who my favorite women characters were, I had to think. He extolled Mrs. Ramsey in Virginia Woolf's To the Lighthouse. I didn't want to be a hostess, even a wise and sensitive one!

I certainly understand Kaitlyn Greenidge's admiration and anger in response to Little Women. Many of us relate to the story in different ways depending on the cultures we're from.  As someone who grew up in a Jewish pocket of the old left in NYC in the mid 20th century, I became obsessed with Louisa May Alcott.  I read everything she wrote including her "thrillers", Transcendental Wild Oats, etc. and including her father's Journal and her mothers entries in that journal. Why? Because I saw similarities between her experiences as part of a small radical culture and my own. Her perspective gave me a way to see the humor in the extremist and idealist vision of my parents and their circle of friends during the "red scare". For me it was scary growing up with so much hostility from the mainstream culture but Louisa May Alcott showed me how to validate my experience and see into how that culture shaped the people who were part of it including myself. There's so much to see in the story of Little Women and in the world Louisa May Alcott grew up in.
Brava (says the non-Italian)!!  Well put all around.  I hope someone adds the story of Ellen Garrison Jackson so that those who want to understand those times can find her story as well.

I don’t see how skin color or other “identity characteristics” have much to do with identifying ( or not) with the protagonist.

 I read Anne Frank in middle school and strongly identified - and empathized - with Anne .... despite the fact that I was not a German Jewish girl. 

Last year I read an excellent new novel called Copperhead - set in rural upstate New York - and strongly identified with the protagonist .... despite the fact that I am not a 17 year old male football star with a white nationalist, Bible-thumping family. 

And the list goes on...

I think we all forget that media is a business, and it was a business when Little Women was written.  Authors usually write books because they want to earn a living and they therefore write what sells.  Hollywood makes movies that they think will bring in more revenues than they cost to make.  Until recently, white people were the majority in this country, and certainly that was the case when Little Women was written, so no surprise it focuses on the white point of view.  To expect otherwise is illogical.  But times are changing, and as long as non whites keep buying movie tickets and streaming non-white themed content, studios will start to cater to those tastes.  Tyler Perry is an admirable example of someone who has found a very profitable niche doing just that.  But to look at Hollywood or literature as anything other than a money making enterprise is probably giving it too much credit.  when blacks drive book sales, you will see a lot of books about black people.  To look for or hope for otherwise is just inventing something that isn't there.  And I'm saddened that a black intellectual feels she has to write an essay on how she actually felt OK going to a movie about white people.  Great stories are great stories regardless of who portrays the characters.  A black guy played Hamilton to rave reviews, right?

Many of us have different backgrounds from the characters in Little Women; little Chinese-American girls, little Indian-American girls, little Orthodox Jewish girls may not immediately think, "oh, I fit into one of the boxes exactly".
Certainly, with my Jewish background, any mention of a Christmas dinner with ham or pork elicits a very conscious reaction of, "that's not me".

But that doesn't mean that *nothing* from Little Women resonates with my daughters. 

Our family knows from a very early age that we are different, and that we can celebrate being different, but we can also take whatever we feel comfortable with from the mainstream culture.

I appreciate this perceptive column.  As a portion of our society works to atone the wrongs of the past (up to the present) and another portion strains equally hard to ignore them, art and literature are in the crosshairs of the culture wars.  It’s refreshing to hear from someone who understands that classic literature doesn’t have to be rejected out-of-hand because David Copperfield wasn’t from a repressed minority (poverty being fairly common in 19th-century London).  And that accepting his whiteness in no way diminishes the wrongs that oppressed minorities suffered and continue to suffer.

Well written and well said! 

"But the questions should be an invitation to creation, not an end to conversation."

I would love to see a film about Ellen Garrison Jackson!

As a 60 y.o. white woman, I am learning to not immediately have a defensive reaction when reading pieces talking about race. I really want to learn now. I thought this was a thoughtful and generous piece. It's such a complicated issue with many levels and scales. In the end, don't we all want to see ourselves in one another-not in superficial terms, but in human terms-our fears, our loves, our hopes and dreams, our  anger, our humility. It is a unique thing to be human compared to everything else on this planet. Indeed, we need to put more focus on that and not on our skin color and type of shoes. We need to have deeper conversations. Thank you for this piece Ms. Greenidge.

Maybe we're getting closer to "post-wokeness" with this sensible approach to literature.

When I read ancient Greek literature, I don't focus on the "Greekness" of the material.  What is striking is the universality of the characters, dilemma and themes.
Alcott herself was marginalized, simply by virtue of being born female. I think she would also appreciate this essay, and the perspective it represents.

Art and entertainment are not therapy or encounter groups.  They may invite empathy but they don't "empathize".

What if looking for or demanding social justice everywhere is just another form of personal vanity?

..."The film I saw was one that explored how the small decisions made in childhood affect a whole life’s trajectory; how gender, birth order, social expectations can raise or dampen a spirit; and the prices paid for rallying against all those constraints to declare a self."....

Does this not float free of any ethnic or racial specificity?

LITTLE WOMEN was something read to me, and that I then read, in my childhood.  I was white and middle class.  I did not understand those two facts separated me out to appreciate the March sisters.  The dynamics of sisters was important to me.  I had a talented older sister with gifts other than my own.  We fought for love within the family but also loved each other.  Of course the book was not written for me.  My family was deeply dysfunctional and finally fractured.  I longed for the ideal family the Marchs represented.  Moral and idealistic.  Dedicated to others.  I grew up and learned that I was no more Jo,Meg,Amy or Beth than anyone else.  I put childish dreams aside for real life.  But when you are a child there is nothing wrong with dreaming.
A good story is a good story . Human experiences , emotions feeling all the same . Just humans being  humans reacting in different ways making the story worth reading

Kaitlyn, thank you for your thoughtful writing. 
Might I add, that very few Christians in America are middle eastern. Very few of us can imagine living in a society or looking like the people who lived in Israel and Egypt 2000+ years ago. Despite that, white, black, hispanic, and asian people read the Bible stories and imagine themselves in those stories. Who has not wondered if they could be so brave as to stand before Goliath? Who has not wondered if they would deny knowing Jesus? 
Human nature transcends.

“Moral fortitude in an immoral world” beautifully and perfectly written as is the entire Op-Ed, thank you. I had never read Little Women, but over winter recess did because it was a source of hope for the heroines of Elena Ferrante’s Neopolitan quartet. The canon is expanding.

Thank you for your perspective on such a complex issue! As an, albeit lefty, middle-aged, white man, I sometimes feel like the poster child for all the ills of the world. This can be confusing for my peers and I as we can easily see all the positive change that has occurred since we were born. But it's also easy to be oblivious to the more sublet semiotics of media, advertising and the larger culture and how they collectively affect children of color. It's not that there's anything wrong with Little Women and it's not that young black girls can't relate to the lot of the young women they hope to become. It's that there's another layer for them. And that layer is woefully underrepresented in the classics--modern or otherwise-- of a country that until recently only had an interests in telling sorties from a monochromatic perspective. And we can only fully understand that when it is pointed out to us because we are sometimes color-blind in a bad way.

As a little girl of ethnic Indian heritage growing up on a South Pacific Island nation in the early 1970s, Little Women was the full novel I read and immediately fell in love with because I saw my own family in the March's.  Even though the book was a slice of life about completely foreign people in an alien land where the ground turned white with snow! Imagine that!

I suppose the need to identify with a book's hero makes sense when the reader is a child. And Little Women is certainly a children's book. 
But hopefully one does outgrow this way of reading. For the best literature is not meant for children, and the reader is not to identify with the protagonist. Do we identify with Flaubert's Emma Bovary? Or with Kafka's K? Thackeray's Becky Sharp? Proust's Marcel? Celine's Ferninand Bardamu?
As hackneyed (or quaint) as it may sound today, literature is a way of exploring the human condition, not making us feel good about ourselves. Tolstoy's characters are Russians - I never mistake them for myself. I admire them, pity them, love them, always aware that their world is not mine.
So happy to have read this! Remembering also reading the classic children's books and having to imagine myself a boy. This is still true.

No one's story is universal. Which is why there needs to be more stories from more people. No one can encompass what it means to be human, or a woman, or black, or a black woman in a single story - or a white man for that matter. Everyone needs stories that reflect their own lives and everyone needs stories that show them the lives of others.

I read voraciously as a young girl and was quite aware that I did not see myself in those books. I loved Little Women then and now but as a young Jewish girl growing up in the 1950’s suburbs of NY I certainly never saw myself in literature. We didn’t celebrate Christmas, have an attic with family heirlooms or even a grandmother to visit on the farm. My grandmother lived in the  Bronx. But I loved books and they transported me to places near and far,  past and present.  Needing books that are more culturally diverse and representative doesn’t negate the beauty  and importance of literature that doesn’t represent you.
Thank you. Well said and kindly thought provoking.   Kaitlyn opens the door wider in her argument of how individuals can immerse themselves in literature and maintain their culturally critical eye.
It must be exhausting to go through life carefully parsing, calculating, and counting the demographic makeup of major cultural works that one consumes every day.

All stories about human beings are stories about all human beings.  There is nothing odd about about seeing yourself in and empathizing with fictional characters from different vantage points.  It's a crutch to obsess over the social construction of race to the point that we deny sharing universal qualities of being human.

I'm a white woman, in my 60's, and I share your perspective in a larger context. Growing up I had to work hard to find myself in any relevant way in history books. The predominant perspective was male, and only male. The only female historic figures we learned about were the iconic Betsy Ross, Florence Nightingale, Madame Curie types. 

When the American Girl books were introduced in the early 1990's I was thrilled because they placed young girls--including Addie, who was black--in historic situations and places in time. My own children grew up with this vitally important perspective, one of inclusion of a female viewpoint. 

Thank you for this thoughtful essay, Ms. Greenridge, and for your generosity.

The defensiveness and irritation in some of these comments is funny. "Why does it always have to be about race? Why can't you just enjoy this book about four white girls which is universally beloved?" All the author is doing is calling attention (extremely gently and subtly) to the fact that some of the classic books considered "universally beloved" are in fact limited slices of life in a limited cultural time and place which at the time was the prevailing culture. She's also reflecting (again gently and subtly) on whether and how a black girl reader could appreciate the book and make  it her own. A wonderful, thought-provoking essay. I'm smarter and have a broader perspective than before I read it.

As an older white woman I cannot presume to walk in Kaitlyn Greenidge's shoes, yet her essay made me feel what I do presume she wanted readers to feel--an empathy for her complex experience with Little Women. 

Even in our age of intense and frequently ugly identity politics, what unites human beings always lurks inside us-"hath [we all] not have eyes...hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions." Whatever that something is, it's tapped into by essays such as this one. 

The power of novels, unlike movies, is that they leave room in the mind for readers to do the imaginative "stretching" of what individual characters look like --so much so that we can insert ourselves into them. The author could feel her place in Little Women just as I felt my place in Junichiro Tanizaki's "The Makioka Sisters" (even though I am obviously a far cry from being a Japanese woman living in a family in Osaka between the wars). 

The word "universalism" is utterly out of fashion. Be that as it may, it accounts for our empathy.
.

This is a beautiful essay that means so much to me after (coincidentally?) having read so many just over the last week decrying the death of the humanities, the death of reading, the death of books written as anything but IP to be optioned by a streaming service. Thank you.

Well done.  I really appreciate the distinction between one viewpoint and a universal viewpoint.
Sometimes these semi-autobiographical stories can hold great power and help outsiders to see the world through another's eyes.  One of my favorite books is Crick Crack Monkey by Merle Hodge.  I am not from Trinidad, but the emotions evoked and the experiences recounted are very moving.
We can all benefit from reading books by diverse authors.  Luckily, the choices are expanding rapidly.
This woman can write!  She is a credit to writers everwhere. I’ll be buying her first book and I hope, others. The best review of Alcott’s story that I have ever read.

Thank you for a wonderful meditation on watching movies and reading literature...and learning deeply from art and others without losing your soul. Few reviews like this are worth rereading, but yours is.
Yes, I identified with Jo, but, like Pecola, I also thought that if I had blue eyes and straight blond hair, my life would be perfect.

Wonderful essay. The overriding problem of the Western literary canon has always been that only one viewpoint mattered -- that of the young to middle aged white male.  When I first encountered Toni Morrison's and Octavia Butler's and Jame's Baldwin's and Langston Hughes' and Nikki Giovanni's  and etc.'s work as a young white man, I found them alien at first, but as I read I found that alien quality resounded with me more than traditional literature, perhaps because of my own loner life. They taught me empathy.

Not every book is about every perspective.   I can't remember fully drawn white characters in anything by Zora Neale Hurston.   Baldwin of course portrays Giovanni in Giovanni's Room, a book by a black man that changed my understanding (as a white teenager) of the world.

For goodness sakes:  Little Women is not about every single thing that happened, nor every person, in a particular set of years in America.   

Alcott herself, and her family, were so ahead of their time as liberal thinkers that it seems best to seek other targets.

OK, start to throw the brickbats at me. Number One, the victimization of the marginalized reader is hardly confined to black people, or black women. ALL women for centuries, or millennia, have had to find ways to identify with, or find relationship to, a fictional universe created mostly by men, especially in elite written literature to which they were denied access. That includes nonwhite cultures. The women's response, which I encourage the article writer and all the other disgruntled, to imitate is that they created their own fiction, often being the ones who constructed and modified the oral folktales which are the world's richest source of literature. And when they achieved power to do so, like Alcott, they created their own rather than complaining about what existed. While we're at it, that goes for people who bash the likes of Kipling, who, with all his faults, created worlds that were NOT simply imperialist (the character Kim is not English but Irish-Indian; Mowgli is not a white boy; Kipling himself was extremely critical of British institutions, which victimized him plenty when he was a child). Where are the novels by those in former colonies attempting sensitively to explore the good as well as the bad in both their own and others' culture, as writers like Conrad and Kipling did, with irony directed at both? Waiting.

"Is empathy really empathy if it’s generally asked to flow in only one direction? Under those circumstances, empathy looks less like identifying with the other and more like emotional hegemony".

That wraps up so much, so succinctly.  It's definitely a concept to consider for a minute.

That this writer sees herself and her family in the characters in literature is the whole point of literature in the first place. To see what is common and human in all of us is what makes literature great, not the literal representation of race or gender. I don't have to look like you or have the same external trappings to feel like you. 

That said, there is also a great deal of room for more literature that reflects other cultures, experiences and traditions. But what makes literature great is that it speaks to the elementally human characteristics, longings, and experiences that unite us all.

Having had the good fortune to both meet and interview Octavia Butler, who died much too young, I, for one, would love to see a movie or miniseries based on "Parable of the Sower" and "Parable of the Talents."
Lauren Olamina and the politically toxic, dangerous world she inhabits would seem to be an excellent parable for our times.

Beautifully written, and I appreciate the closeness among the author's own sisters and niece, and their bonding over the stories observed in movies they watch together. I like this distinction: "Isn’t reading fiction an exercise in empathy? But empathy for whom, and for what higher purpose, always complicates this supposedly benevolent action. Is empathy really empathy if it’s generally asked to flow in only one direction?" That's exactly why I find most movies, or novels, impossible to watch, since they tend to reflect the "one direction" of male characters and reduce girls and women to "props" or erotic objects. A rare few women authors (Alcott, Austen, the Brontes, et al) have given women readers & filmgoers the narrative sustenance they have craved over the years. As Austen wrote, "Men have had every advantage of us in telling their own story. .. the pen has been in their hands." There was so much good acting, but there were many in the cast that I'd not had the opportunity to earlier experience their acting.   The solution path requires thought, but where a role doesn't *require* a specific ethnicity (or gender), casting should be color-blind, so-to-speak; that is, where the role is not about or centered on an ethnicity it should be open to cast anyone with the right skills. There's accumulating evidence that audiences of all backgrounds can relate to and appreciate performances by minority actors.

The media have not paid enough attention to Chief Justice Roberts' decision striking down the Affordable Care Act's requirement that states expand Medicaid, or lose federal funding for that program.  In essence, Roberts ruled that once it creates a program that states come to find useful (such as Medicaid), Congress may not thereafter threaten to eliminate that program as a way to "blackmail" states into running that program in particular ways. 

This is, of course, a novel principle--and one that no serious observer expects the Court to extend to other areas of law.  The rationale was a makeweight--a means for Roberts to throw a bone to conservatives otherwise outraged that he did not provide the fifth vote required to hold the entire ACA unconstitutional. Consider the implications of the Medicaid holding's logic: The federal government could almost never choose to discontinue a major program. I discovered Rush in 1981, just after Moving Pictures came out, and saw them live for the first time on their Signals tour.  I learned their entire catalog through Grace Under Pressure on guitar, and every song on air drums.  The air drums were more difficult to play! I wrote my college application essay on Neil Peart, about how I admired his integrity and intellect under the glare of the spotlight.

As I aged through college, early adulthood, and middle age, my lust for hard rock and instrumental virtuosity waned, as jazz became the bulk of my listening, and Neil's rigid perfection was replaced in my musical brain by a preference for improvisation.

But as I got older, something else happened. The desire for meaning, for art that was reflective, for something that could capture my increasingly jaded imagination - became more important than ever before.  Neil Peart's lyrics have always given me that, and still do.

While he inspired a generation of drummers, it Neil's body of lyrical poetry that will be his true legacy.  His ideas on so many topics - both real and fantasy - will continue to capture the soul of listeners for generations to come.  I need not look any further than my 15 year old daughter, whose own existential turmoil has been relieved by the lyrics to Analog Kid and Subdivisions.  She may not memorize the drum fills, but she's already singing along.

Goodbye Professor.  Your place in the history of music, and in our hearts, is assured.

One of the fascinating things about Rush was that there were only 3 of them creating such a massive "wall" of sound. Because there were only three of them, and each a virtuoso, you could focus your attention and follow along with any one of them, and clearly hear (often in disbelief) every note that each of them played. 

By comparison, much rock music is thick and heavy, and try as you might, you often can't tell who is playing what, or can't easily follow along with any one of the instruments. To be able to do so with Rush, allowed you to fully appreciate the technical prowess of each of the 3 musicians, but more than that, indulge in the pure artistry of their compositions.

The Rush Backstage Club was a newsletter I subscribed to in my teen years. Unlike today’s instant blogosphere, one had to wait many months for a 4 page leaflet to arrive.  To read Neil waxing poetic and philosophic about all his eclectic interests and chronicle his travels was the payoff, well worth the anticipation.  To see him with his mustached visage reading “A confederacy of Dunces” with his cigarette billowing smoke suggested that one could be intellectually curious and cool.  To listen to his drumming and lyrics while reading was otherworldly and it provided the refuge and solace that was so necessary to us adolescent musicians and young men struggling to fit in, whatever that meant.  His music was the elixir that liberated our minds and spirits, inspiring us to lose ourselves in art, literature, philosophy, sci-fi and not compromise or conform.  His lyrics conveyed the message just be yourself, and that is more than good enough. Rest In Peace Neil, and thank you.
